title: Additional Resources
text:
The following videos come from Dr. Mike Young, Professor of Physics at Santa Barbara City College. These lectures utilize the 7th edition of Serway’s Physics for Scientists and Engineers, which bests align with the content covered in PHY 121 and PHY 131. Since each video is roughly two hours, I recommend watching the videos in chunks over the span of each week (preferably before the material is covered).

Physics 1: Mechanics - SBCC Physics 121 Spring 2015

Covers Chapters 1-14 for PHY 121

Physics 2: Electricity and Magnetism - SBCC Physics 122 Fall 2013

Covers Chapters 23-34 for PHY 131

Physics 3: Waves, Thermodynamics, Light, and Modern Physics - SBCC Physics 123 Spring 2014

Videos 1-4 cover Chapters 15, 16, and 17 for PHY 121
Videos 16-22 cover Chapters 35, 36, and 37 for PHY 131


For more digestible videos, I have found these helpful to review for exams. Since these videos may use a different textbook, the order and notation of the material may slightly vary from what is shown in class.

Physics 1: Khan Academy India - Class 11 Physics
Physics 2: Khan Academy India - Class 12 Physics
General Physics: Organic Chemistry Tutor - Physics Lessons By Chapter

Chapters 1-13 cover the concepts for PHY 121
Chapters 17-28 cover the concepts for PHY 131

General Physics: Flipping Physics

AP Physics C: Mechanics covers Chapters 1-15 for PHY 121
AP Physics C: Electricity and Magnetism covers Chapters 23-34 for PHY 131

General Physics: San Diego State University - Physics with Professor Matt Anderson

Modules 1-15 cover the concepts for PHY 121
Modules 16-27 cover the concepts for PHY 131

The Physics Classroom - Physics Tutorial

title: University Physics I/II Review
text:
Welcome! The purpose of this site is offer a brief overview of the material covered for the following courses at Arizona Western College:

PHY 121: University Physics I (Syllabus)

Introduction to mechanics. Analysis of the interactions between a system and its environment to determine changes in the system’s position, velocity, momentum, and mechanical energy. Application of Newton’s laws and conservation laws to the behavior of physical systems.

PHY 131: University Physics II (Syllabus)

Introduction to electricity and magnetism. Application of the laws of electricity and magnetism to the behavior of physical systems.


Both classes use the 9th Edition of Physics for Scientists and Engineers with Modern Physics by Serway and Jewett. All homework problems are assigned from this textbook.

PHY 121 covers Chapters 1-17 from Physics and Measurements to Sound Waves
PHY 131 covers Chapters 23-37 from Electric Fields to Wave Optics
If time permits, PHY 131 may briefly cover part of the material from Chapter 18 on Standing Waves and Chapter 42 on Atomic Physics

Feel free to check out a recommended list of resources in the Resources tab. Best of luck!

title: Electric Fields
text: This first chapter covers three of six key quantities we will need to analyze how charges behave. These quantities are the electric charge, force, and field. We will discuss how they arise and relate to each other.

title: Electric Fields
text:
Electrical Charge
Just like color, density, mass, etc., charge is not a physical object, but rather a property of an object. We use charge to describe how objects interact in an electric and magnetic field.






New Unit: Coulomb



The SI unit for charge is the Coulomb [C].


Objects can fall into three main categories:

Positively charged objects have more protons than electrons
Negatively charged objects have more electrons than protons
Neutral objects have an equal number of protons and electrons

We often call protons (positively charged) and electrons (negatively charged) charge carriers, since freely moving electrons are responsible for charge transfer. Below are couple useful parameters for the proton, electron, and neutron:



Particle
Charge [C]
Mass [kg]




Proton
\[ 1.60 \times 10^{-19} \]
\[ 1.67 \times 10^{-27} \]


Electron
\[ -1.60 \times 10^{-19} \]
\[ 9.11 \times 10^{-31} \]


Neutron
\[ 0 \]
\[ 1.67 \times 10^{-27} \]









Fundamental Observation



Opposite charges attract and like charges repel.

title: Electric Fields
text:
Coulomb’s Law
The electric force between two point charges is:
\[
F = k_e \frac{|q_1||q_2|}{r^2}
\]

title: Electric Fields
section: Electric Field from a Point Charge
text:
Electric Field from a Point Charge
\[
E = \frac{F}{q} = k_e \frac{|q|}{r^2}
\]

title: Electric Fields
text:
Example Problem
Two charges of ( +3, ) and ( -2, ) are placed 0.5 m apart. What is the electric field halfway between them?

title: RC Circuits
text:
Discharging a Capacitor
\[
q(t) = Q_{\text{max}} e^{-t/RC}
\]

title: RC Circuits
text:
Time Constant
\[
\tau = RC
\]
This is the time it takes for the capacitor to reach ~63% of full charge.
